s.text: Bill Paxon, a Gingrich minion at the National Republican Congressional Committee, the party's fund-raising and spending apparatus that helped win the House for the GOP in 1994, is enthusiastic and smart but doesn't seem tough enough to be speaker.
"It is high time," Huffington wrote, "for some young Turks to recognize that there are moments when appeasement is more destructive than war--and to strike."

Bill Paxon, a Gingrich minion at the National Republican Congressional Committee, the party's fund-raising and spending apparatus that helped win the House for the GOP in 1994, is enthusiastic and smart but doesn't seem tough enough to be speaker.

Instead of giving artful non-answers to tough questions--a prerequisite talent for politicians--Armey usually lets fly a smart-aleck comment that gets him in trouble: Soon after becoming majority leader, he referred to Rep.
But after a shaky first few months in charge, Armey settled in as the House's relatively effective chief operating officer.
But after a shaky first few months in charge, Armey settled in as the House's relatively effective chief operating officer.
Having already paid too high a political price for Gingrich's failings, Republican incumbents don't want another headache leading the party.
Those who worry about how the ruffian image will play should Armey become speaker can rest easy: As both angler and politician, one Armey admirer told me, "He's catch-and-release."
A geeky economics professor with a Midwestern accent challenging an entrenched Texas Democrat, Armey was given no chance of winning.
